milestone.description:
- Reliability: consistently perform its intended function without errors, crashes or other failures. Handle edge cases and unexpected inputs.
- Performance: fast, reasonable response times even under heavy load. Efficient in the use of system resources.
- Usability: intuitive and easy to use, clear and concise documentation and logs, helpful error messages.
- Security:  protect against attacks like hacking, data breaches and other security threats.
- Compatibility: work with other software and hardware systems.
- Maintainability: easy to maintain and update with modular and well-documented code. Easy to troubleshoot and debug when issues arise.

### Description

Added an `OR` condition to the CI workflow to trigger tests by leaving a comment to the PR (`@test_pls` 🧎 ). This should allows one to trigger CI tests instead of relying on review approval from others as we currently do.

Also added a few links in README that should help with supporting visitors to the repo

### Linked issue
Resolves #137

body:
### Description

To enable the radio to operate seemlessly between sessions, this PR
- adds `PersistedState` struct to track local attestations and remote messages, it should later track comparison result as well.
- adds periodic event to update the persisted state cache.
- allows users to provide a file path that retains the radio state for local attestations and remote messages.
- enables integrations tests to query radio states without going inside of radio operations.
- enables future functional refactoring of radio states

### Issue link (if applicable)

Resolves #113

### Checklist
- [x] Are tests up-to-date with the new changes? 
- [x] Are docs up-to-date with the new changes? (Open PR on docs repo if necessary)

@test_pls

title: Attestation result ratio str query

milestone.description:
- Reliability: consistently perform its intended function without errors, crashes or other failures. Handle edge cases and unexpected inputs.
- Performance: fast, reasonable response times even under heavy load. Efficient in the use of system resources.
- Usability: intuitive and easy to use, clear and concise documentation and logs, helpful error messages.

body:
### Description

(Repeated PR bc of stupidity with git rebase: https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/pull/133)

### Description

Provide a clear aggregation of the attestations from remote messages with optional filters

```
  stakeRatio(filter: {deployment: "__", blockNumber: "___"}){
    deployment
    blockNumber
    compareRatio
  }
  
  senderRatio{
    deployment
    blockNumber
    compareRatio
  }
  
```

will provide a string of compare Ratio. 

Examples with sender ratio

- `x/y!/z` where x, y, z are sorted by descending stake weights, and `!` indicates the entry that correspond to the local result. 

- `2/0!` means there are 2 indexers attesting with higher sum of stake weight, and no other indexer has the same nPOI as us.

- `8!` means there are 8 other indexers agreeing with us. 

### Issue link (if applicable)

Improvement for #93 

### Checklist
- [ ] Are tests up-to-date with the new changes? 
- [ ] Are docs up-to-date with the new changes? (Open PR on docs repo if necessary)

title: disable unsubscribe and use timeout
body:
### Description

Currently the main event loop of POI radio consist of different types of events that makes sense to execute on different frequencies. Namely there is content topic updates and gossip of the POIs; in the upcoming features, there would be the separation of indexing status updates and gossip of deployment health. We have observed that a particular event may get stuck and block all other operations. 

This PR separate the concerns by adding execution frequencies and event timeouts. Potential next steps are to add a struct to keep all intervals/durations, and to allow user configurations.

### Issue link (if applicable)

Motivated by #115

### Checklist
- [ ] Are tests up-to-date with the new changes? 
- [ ] Are docs up-to-date with the new changes? (Open PR on docs repo if necessary)

title: refactor: gossip poi refactoring and add benches
body:
### Description

This PR utilize criterion crate to track the performance of functions. We start off by setting up a few benches to operations that are specific to the POI radio.

Be aware that criterion has the downside of being slower than cargo bench (only available in the nightly build) and experiences small threshold issues for micro-benchmarks.

Micro-benchmarks
- update_block
- update_attestation
- compare_attestations
- comparison_point  

Macro-benchmarks
- gossip_poi: the event loop to set up messages, send messages, and compare messages.

To run the benchmarks, install `cargo-bench` and then run `cargo bench` to see the performances measured across 100 trials

Use `cargo benchcmp` to compare with pervious results such as 
```
cargo bench > before
cargo bench > after
cargo benchcmp before after
```

Example output
```
update_block            time:   [1.4177 µs 1.4188 µs 1.4203 µs]
Found 7 outliers among 100 measurements (7.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high mild
  6 (6.00%) high severe

update_attestation      time:   [1.5889 µs 1.5940 µs 1.6034 µs]
Found 11 outliers among 100 measurements (11.00%)
  2 (2.00%) low mild
  2 (2.00%) high mild
  7 (7.00%) high severe

compare attestations    time:   [1.3625 µs 1.4217 µs 1.4851 µs]
                        change: [+1.7717% +5.6871% +9.9972%] (p = 0.01 < 0.05)
                        Performance has regressed.
Found 1 outliers among 100 measurements (1.00%)
  1 (1.00%) low mild

comparison point        time:   [307.76 ns 311.80 ns 316.05 ns]
Found 8 outliers among 100 measurements (8.00%)
  5 (5.00%) high mild
  3 (3.00%) high severe

     Running benches/gossips.rs (target/release/deps/gossips-aec1915445bd88b4)
gossip_poi              time:   [1.0675 µs 1.0779 µs 1.0961 µs]
                        change: [-2.5360% -1.6806% -0.8009%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Change within noise threshold.
Found 17 outliers among 100 measurements (17.00%)
  1 (1.00%) high mild
  16 (16.00%) high severe


```

### Issue link (if applicable)

Closes #110 

### Checklist

- [ ] Have you tested your changes?
- [ ] Does this PR include changes that require our documentation to be updated, if so, have you created a PR on the docs repo to make the necessary changes?

title: fix: return empty vec if indexer_allocations function fails
body:
### Description
Modified `active_allocation_hashes` to return an empty vec if the query response (`result.indexer_allocations()`) has errors.  No need for a retry mechanism because `generate_topics` is already being called periodically in `main.rs` (L143):
```rust
if Utc::now().timestamp() % 120 == 0 {
    GRAPHCAST_AGENT
        .get()
        .unwrap()
        .update_content_topics(generate_topics().await)
        .await;
}
```
### Issue link (if applicable)
https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/issues/109

title: Expose API endpoint
body: ### Description Default to spin up server at `localhost:7700` (refactor in the SDK to provide server-host, server-port) Available routes - `/health` for health status - `/metrics` for http service metrics about the server - `/api/v1/graphql` for GET and POST requests with playground interface Example Basic queries ``` schema { query: QueryRoot } # A wrapper around an attested NPOI, tracks Indexers that have sent it plus their accumulated stake type Attestation { npoi: String! stakeWeight: Int! senders: [String!]! senderGroupHash: String! timestamp: [Int!]! } type AttestationEntry { deployment: String! blockNumber: Int! attestation: Attestation! } # GraphcastMessage type casts over radio payload type GraphcastMessage { # Graph identifier for the entity the radio is communicating about identifier: String! # content to share about the identified entity payload: RadioPayloadMessage # nonce cached to check against the next incoming message nonce: Int! # blockchain relevant to the message network: String! # block relevant to the message blockNumber: Int! # block hash generated from the block number blockHash: String! # signature over radio payload signature: String! } type QueryRoot { radioPayloadMessages: [GraphcastMessage!]! radioPayloadMessagesByDeployment(identifier: String!): [GraphcastMessage!]! localAttestations: [AttestationEntry!]! localAttestationsByDeployment(identifier: String!): [AttestationEntry!]! localAttestationsByDeploymentBlock( identifier: String! block: Int! ): [AttestationEntry!]! } type RadioPayloadMessage { identifier: String! content: String! } ``` ### Issue link (if applicable) Resolves #86 ### Next step - Utilize graphQL resolver `where` filter instead of creating new query functions - Create more complex and useful resolvers ### Checklist - [x] Have you tested your changes? - [ ] Does this PR include changes that require our documentation to be updated, if so, have you created a PR on the docs repo to make the neccessary changes? - Not yet

title: feat: move integration tests to main repo

labels.name: rust
labels.description: Pull requests that update Rust code

body:
### Description
Adds integration tests + Github workflow to run in CI.

#### How to run
Before running the tests, make sure you
- Have Docker running
- Have populated the `.env` file

Then, simply run `./run-e2e-tests.sh` from the root folder. If all tests pass, you should see this kind of summary report at the end of the logs:
```bash
Summary Report:
-------------------------------------
Total Tests Run: 5
Successful Tests: 5
Failed Tests: 0
Timed Out Tests: 0
Test Suite Duration: 17m 21s
-------------------------------------
```
If however one or more tests fail, the script will dump the error logs into a `logs/failed_tests_logs.log` file.

#### What these tests cover
These tests are a combination of _setup_ instances found in `integration-tests/src/setup` (responsible for sending different kinds of messages depending on the test scenario, these instances will only send messages and not process incoming ones) and _check_ instances in `integration-tests/src/checks` (that perform the actual assertions).

The _checks_ include:
- `simple_tests`
    1. `clear_store` checks if the store is properly removing old messages.
    2. `store_attestations` checks if the storing and processing of messages works on a high level, also it makes sure the processing messages and sorting attestation bits work properly.
    3. `comparison_interval` makes sure the comparison interval is working
    4. `skip_messages_from_self` makes sure that the messages that the current instance sends are not being received by it.
    5. `simple_receiver` is another simple health check that makes sure that messages are being received, without going more in depth about whether they've been properly processed or not. This can help diagnosing errors early on.
    6. `correct_filtering_default_topics` makes sure the instance is receiving messages for the default topics it is subscribed to.
    7. `correct_filtering_different_topics` makes sure we're not receiving and processing messages that have topics different than the ones we are subscribed to.
    8. `num_messages` is another simple health check-type test.
- `invalid_messages`
    This suite makes sure that the Radio is not validating messages that have invalid block hash, invalid nonce or invalid payload structure.
 - `invalid_sender`
     This suite makes sure that the Radio is not validating messages that have an invalid sender (less than minimum required stake).
 - `poi_divergence_local`
     This test makes sure that if there's a divergence between local nPOI and the remote one with the most stake tied to it, it will perform the comparison function properly.
 - `poi_divergence_remote`
          This test makes sure that if there isn't a divergence between local nPOI and the remote one with the most stake tied to it, but there is more than one remote nPOI, it will perform the comparison function properly.

#### How it works
On a high level the script performs the following tasks:

1. Reads or exports environment variables
2. Creates a logs directory if it doesn't exist
3. Defines variables related to testing and containers
4. Starts containers using `docker-compose`
5. Waits for containers to start and settle
6. Runs a series of tests with various timeouts
7. Scales up/down containers as needed for specific tests
8. Captures and logs test results
9. Stops containers
10. Prints a summary report of test results

### Checklist
- [x] Have you tested your changes? 
- [x] Does this PR include changes that require our documentation to be updated, if so, have you created a PR on the docs repo to make the necessary changes?

### Next steps
Use [conditional compilation](https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/conditional-compilation.html) to further embed the test code to the prod code (`/src`).

body:
### Description

Use `tokio::spawn` for operating send and compare messages in different threads for deployments to improve operation efficiency.
Refactored the main loop for readability.

### Issue link (if applicable)
Resolves #66 

---
Wanted to add [benchmarking](https://github.com/bheisler/criterion.rs) to observe the effects for parallelizing tasks to send and compare messages by deployments, but seems to make more sense to test a single function at a time (by implementing them in a benchmark file) instead of measuring main function directly.

title: fix: more guarantees for message uniqueness

labels.name: rust
labels.description: Pull requests that update Rust code

body:
**Issue**
The nPOI comparison is currently failing because messages are sent for the same block when the loop to send messages is shorter than the interval of examination frequency, messages are considered different by the receiver because they were sent with different nonces, but then upon receiving the message with the same block from an existing sender fails the comparison process (when the messages from the store get processed).

With this PR we make sure to only send 1 message (=1 nPOI) for a given block for a given subgraph id.

✅ Tested with the help of e2e tests branch.
✅ No docs update needed.

title: feat: attestation indexer sender group sort and hash

milestone.title: Radio stable functionality
milestone.description:
mini-milestone to stabilize the radio functionality

1. Fix comapre_attestations issue (fixed with item 2)
2. Prometheus metrics - [issue](https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/issues/61)
    1. Basic prometheus setup in Radio ([pr](https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/pull/75))
    2. dependency: Indexer attestation groups - [issue](https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/issues/60)
3. Docker releases with semver + watchtower (semvar tag [pr](https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/pull/72))
4. Fix peer count issue ([issue](https://github.com/graphops/graphcast-sdk/issues/147) -> [pr](https://github.com/graphops/graphcast-sdk/pull/151)
5. Prune old messages ([issue](https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/issues/70), [pr](https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/pull/78)
6. Topic coverage levels and toggle: ([levels issue](https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/issues/67) and [toggle issue](https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/issues/62) -> [pr](topics leveling, stake weight by active status, improve logs)
7. **Docs**

body:
### Description

- Added indexer group hash field for `Attestation` struct
- Group hash generated upon creating and updating Attestation 
  - First sort indexer addresses, decode address hex string to bytes, then hashed with sha3-256 hasher
- Refactored Attestation operations to its own file
- Unified errors for Attesatations functions

There's no further operations acting on top of the hash at the moment - this would fit better as a metrics label, as Attestations does not live beyond a comparison period, so given a deployment, we won't have the hash for 2 blocks at the same time; nor will we have access for 2 different deployments at the same time. 

### Issue link (if applicable)
Resolves #60

title: fix: compare attestations now checking all local entries

labels.name: rust
labels.description: Pull requests that update Rust code

body:
### Description
Pulled out just the compare attestations fix from https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/pull/75

### Issue link (if applicable)
Fixes https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/issues/76

title: feat: pruning local+remote after expiry, update collect window to local
body:
### Description
Instead of using remote stored messages for determining the comparison trigger, use local attestations. 
- updated attestation struct to include timestamp
- For each identifier, find the smallest block and its timestamp for comparison trigger
- After comparing attestation for a certain deployment+block, prune corresponding remote messages and local attestations with equal or earlier block number.

### Issue link (if applicable)
Resolves #70

title: fix: Updated pull request template
body:
### Description
Updated the pull request template to add a checklist. I've added this checklist so we can ensure that we're more diligent with our pull requests.

N/A

title: topics leveling, stake weight by active status, improve logs
body:
### Description

- Split topic generation into 3 levels as allowed by graphops/graphcast-sdk#150
  - Static: only subscribe to user provided topics
  - OnChain: Same as before, deployments with an active allocation, querying network subgraph
  - Comprehensive: Additional from OnChain, also query Graph node's indexing statuses for the ones with a good index node, i.e. deployment with node not "removed".
- General updates to the SDK
- More precise logging for Operational Summary: include blocks info, complete tracking of non-attested deployments
- Cleaner logging for printing local attestations

### Issue link (if applicable)
Resolves #62 
Resolves #67

title: refactor: logging improvement
body:
### Description

- In each main loop, info log on network chainhead, number of gossip peers, and number of tracked deployments (topics). At the end of main loop, info log on attestation results (number of checks, success, not found, and the details of divergence)
- indexer id stored and show when attesting
- added network name and deployment hash when printing block info
- Update naming of `message block` to `send message block`, and `compare block` to `compare time`

examples
```
  2023-03-15T18:49:03.854408Z  INFO graphcast_sdk::graphql::client_graph_node: Updated latest block pointers for 358 number of subgraphs

1 out of 5 deployments cross checked

```

title: refactor: improve compare attestations logs

labels.name: rust
labels.description: Pull requests that update Rust code

body:
### Description

This PR refactors the `compare_attestations` function to improve its clarity, modularity and testability. The main changes are:

- Adding a custom error type (`ComparisonErr`) instead of `anyhow::Error`
- Switching to pattern matching instead of nested match statements
- Reformatted error messages

### Issue link (if applicable)
https://github.com/graphops/graphcast-sdk/issues/118

### Next steps

We should think about whether we want to keep treating POI divergence as an `Error` or not. Maybe the function could just return an enum, something like `Result<ComparisonResult, Error>`, where `Divergent` is just another variant of `ComparisonResult`.

feat: env config message collect duration
body:
### Description

- Added logs during attestation process.
- Fixed a bug that is after compare_attestations returns, it cleared all the messages but should be only the ones attested (subgraph and block number specific)
- Allow wait duration configuration `COLLECT_MESSAGE_DURATION` between message_block and attestation block for all networks
- Update wait duration to be time based (seconds) instead of by blocks
- Calculate the comparison trigger - filter by identifier then get the smallest block_number and nonce, add the configured duration.

### Issue link (if applicable)
Resolves #40

title: feat: tweak check for comparison trigger
body: Changes the comparison trigger logic to be `latest block >= compare block` instead of `latest block == compare block`. Also adds more debug logs.

title: feat: use indexing status to query block info
body:
### Description
Move away from block provider based triggering to network monitor and syncing status from Graph node.

- added a query function that updates the network chainhead hashmap, and returns Subgraph: (network, latest_block) hashmap. (A bit complicated and can probably be refactored in the near future)
- Poll indexingStatuses every 5 seconds from graph node for the above hashmaps
- Match for network and the appropriate examination block, query POI on the examination block
- Removed block providers from the radio, it is still required for `GraphcastAgent` for signing messages and resolve GraphcastID address

### Issue link (if applicable)
Resolves #33

title: feat: add multichain block clock

labels.name: rust
labels.description: Pull requests that update Rust code

body:
Adds `BlockClock`, `Network` (structs) and `NetworkName` (enum) in order for us to have better typing around the multichain elements.

Partially advances https://github.com/graphops/graphcast-sdk/issues/88 

Next steps: 
1. Move parts that can be generalised into the SDK
2. Potentially move `BlockClock` into `Network` as per suggestion here https://github.com/graphops/poi-radio/pull/30#discussion_r1106324200
3. Improve error handling, we still have a ton of `unwrap`s in `main.rs`

title: subgraph indexing network specific POI query
body:
### Description
Reorder POI generation query
- Add `indexingStatuses` query to the graph node for the `network`.
- Based on the network returned, select the block provider provided by the user (`provider_endpoints`) to query for latest block number. This could be queried from the graph node directly but we are using the providers for deterministic send_message block consensus.
- Based on the network returned, select the block examination frequency in networks supported by the radio (`SUPPORTED_NETWORK_BLOCK_INTERVALS`).
- Query block hash from the graph node, with block provider as a fallback if failed (`blockHashFromNumber`).
- Query POI with network specific block number and block hash.

For the feature to work completely, I think we still need 
- Network specific `compare_block` instead of just one number.
- Testing the combination of subgraphs from several different networks.

Later we can refactor parts of the logic to the SDK. Also, we should review the ordering of queries for efficiency and minimal calls to block provider and graph node.

### Issue link (if applicable)
Partially resolves graphops/graphcast-sdk#88

This PR fixes conflicts with the main branch on the SDK and introduces a workflow file to build and upload docker images to Github's container registry.

title: refactor: fix release binaries workflow
body: This PR fixes the workflow file that builds and uploads the release binaries for Ubuntu and MacOS.

title: Refactor: Add tracing
body:
Adds tracing to improve logging, as done in the SDK with https://github.com/graphops/graphcast-sdk/pull/53 

Next steps:
- When error handling is improved logs should make much more sense, we shouldn't use the `error` level so much, since a lot of things are actually a `warning`
- Currently the tracing subscriber setup is being handled entirely by the SDK and imported in Radios with with `init_tracing()`, but I think we should allow a bit more freedom to Radio devs and let them optionally configure the subscriber however they like.

title: refactor: improve Dockerfile
body:
The current `Dockerfile` in `main` does not work on host machines running `amd` architectures (it would only work if the `Dockerfile` is used on MacOS, not Linux).

With these updates, it should work no matter what the host machine is, it should be OS and architecture agnostic.

The main issue was the Go binary, since it requires a different binary for different operating systems and architectures.

Has been tested on MacOS and Debian.

title: feat: self-defined radio definition
body:
### Description
Use self defined radio definition instead of the pre-defined Graphcast-SDK radio payload definition.

### Issue link (if applicable)
Closes #11

title: feat: build binaries and images
body:
- Adds `Dockerfile` and `docker-compose.yml` files to specify how a Docker image is built and executed (we install and configure everything, then one 1 boot node in the background and 1 light node in the foreground).

- Adds a Github workflow script to build and upload binaries each time a new release is manually created.

title: Setup for integration tests
body:
### Description
This PR demonstrates a way to write integration tests for radios, using Wiremock and a bash script. 

The bash script does a few things:
1. Spins up a test boot node (process sent to background) that the light nodes will connect with.
2. Spins up N number of test light nodes(processes sent to background) to send messages to each other (currently set to 3)
3. Spins up one last light node in the foreground (logs are shown in the terminal that the test script was started from) that checks if it has received 4 messages and when it has - it stops, successfully demonstrating that the nodes are working properly and that messages are propagating and being handled by the `attestation_handler` function.

To do this, the bash script runs the `regression_test` test (which is a normal async Rust test, so we get the full benefit of the cargo testing tools). The test itself demonstrates how to use [wiremock-rs](https://github.com/LukeMathWalker/wiremock-rs) in order to mock the registry and network subgraphs (it can be used to mock anything that a Radio might need from a third party API).

The `regression_test` itself is rather simple, because after the messages are validated and handled, they're passed over to the `process_messages` function, which is already thoroughly tested by the existing unit tests.

**To run the integration test, use this command (after making the script executable):**
```
./run-tests.sh
```

### Issue link (if applicable)
Will close https://github.com/graphops/graphcast-sdk/issues/32

### Possible improvements and next steps
- This is just the ground work for integration testing, a lot more test cases can be written for the POI Radio, and also more generic examples can be developed for documentation and tutorial purposes.
- Currently, the tests use `test-poi-crosschecker-radio` as a Radio name for the test instances, but if two developers are testing the same Radio at the same time that will include noise. I'm leaving it for a future improvement, one way to solve it would be to generate a random UUID or something and append it to the Radio name, in order to guarantee that the test instances are not receiving any outside data.
- There can be a better way to run the integration tests, such as a custom cargo command that runs the bash script.
- The test is marked as with `#[ignore]` for now because I thought it would be best to separate it from the unit tests, also it doesn't run properly when using `nextest`, but in the future we could combine them though.

PS This PR still uses the (forked SDK repo)[https://github.com/axiomatic-aardvark/graphcast-sdk] as a dependency. Once [this PR](https://github.com/graphops/graphcast-sdk/pull/39) is merged, we can merge this one.
